2ef71646-35c7-44d2-854c-81ef5a3e1668.llm_explanation: HashSet uses the equals() and hashCode() methods to determine if two objects are considered the same for storage; if both methods indicate equality, only one is stored.

a44a9f17-efce-460b-b216-93f1cfb78e61.llm_explanation: HashSet allows both objects if equals() returns false, regardless of hashCode(). If hashCode() is the same but equals() is false, both are stored as distinct elements.

0839163e-1e50-4227-abb6-a1a82a75f4d1.llm_explanation: HashSet uses both equals() and hashCode() to determine uniqueness; both must be overridden consistently to ensure correct behavior with custom objects.

d18d985a-4233-46e0-8fc0-7f4b23d31769.llm_explanation: HashSet uses both equals() and hashCode() to determine object uniqueness; both must be overridden consistently to prevent logical duplicates.

5583f5f0-0180-4c97-a7b9-0ffe7aa933d7.llm_explanation: HashSet uses both hashCode() and equals(), but ultimately relies on equals() to determine if an element is a duplicate, rejecting new elements that are equal to existing ones even if they are different objects.

7b30b892-02cc-42d6-875b-80254e487d76.llm_explanation: In a Java Map, each key must be unique and is used to retrieve its corresponding value; duplicate keys are not allowed.

a492c724-7744-46b2-9bdd-91b5c1285efd.llm_explanation: In Java, all keys in a Map must be unique; duplicate keys are not allowed regardless of their values.

2f879baa-b64b-44f0-8f79-cbf2b78ebdd8.llm_explanation: A Java Map stores key-value pairs where each key is unique; duplicate keys are not allowed, but values can be duplicated.

fe45f4aa-6e1c-4b8f-9507-7f38b2046daf.llm_explanation: In Java Maps, calling put() with an existing key replaces the old value with the new one for that key.

a72b5ef4-ce2e-4ced-a3cb-8494950af0d6.llm_explanation: Calling put() with an existing key replaces the old value with the new one; no duplicates or exceptions occur.

31dd921d-3ea2-47ed-8683-880d7c2cbacc.llm_explanation: In Java, the put() method of a Map replaces the old value with the new value if the key already exists, so only one value is associated with each key.

ff55ba62-45ac-42c9-a56d-b0ca4364896e.llm_explanation: map.replace("Bob", 35) updates the value only if "Bob" is already present; other options either always update or only insert if absent.

733c13cf-ad7b-4518-82eb-129b6db21cdb.llm_explanation: map.replace("Alice", 35) updates the value for 'Alice' only if it already exists; otherwise, it does nothing. This matches the requirement exactly.

dc403517-c879-4b3e-875f-d6ddeda990fb.llm_explanation: Option D checks if the key exists before updating its value, ensuring the update only occurs if 'Alice' is already present. The other options either always insert or do not update if present.

3bdd5c39-a353-4839-96db-33a7a2dc18e3.llm_explanation: In a HashMap, adding a value with an existing key replaces the old value with the new one; thus, 28 replaces 25 for the key 'Alice'.

2a789877-e639-4467-b298-3749f171fdba.llm_explanation: In Java, inserting a new value for an existing key in a Map replaces the old value; duplicate keys are not allowed.

76940d6a-699b-48fd-963e-a6029ac2c12b.llm_explanation: In Java, Map.put(key, value) replaces the value for an existing key; so 'Alice' will now map to 40, replacing 25.

a83b0bde-dd5c-4978-b151-134c12103af6.llm_explanation: Calling map.put("K2", 30000) replaces the old value (28251) with the new value (30000) for the existing key "K2"; no exception is thrown and no duplicate keys are created.

7c452569-7e79-44ea-9a57-033d5179910e.llm_explanation: Calling map.put("Alice", 35) replaces the existing value (25) for the key "Alice" with 35; HashMap allows overwriting values for existing keys.

65ad0877-7b96-4aed-9ff3-567a082029a9.llm_explanation: In Java's HashMap, inserting a value with a key that already exists replaces the old value with the new one; no duplicate entry is created and no exception is thrown.

a51ee8bf-91a7-4d78-9451-6d0a6b7dd04e.llm_explanation: The hasNext() method of the Iterator interface is used to check if there are more elements to iterate over in a Java Collection.

edfc357f-afb0-4529-94f5-332303efd954.llm_explanation: The Iterable interface provides the standard way to traverse elements in a Collection via its iterator() method; Iterator is used to perform the traversal, but Iterable defines the standard mechanism.

f446e998-cb38-4797-bb52-85ef64440328.llm_explanation: The hasNext() method of Iterator checks if there are more elements to iterate over in a Java Collection.

815cda7f-b366-4c07-a9b1-593bbe2da7c4.llm_explanation: The primary purpose of an Iterator is to provide sequential access to collection elements without exposing the collection's internal structure.

e4f4ff82-d7f2-4c30-a29b-92d0a55d584e.llm_explanation: The scene graph in JavaFX is a hierarchical structure of nodes that represent all UI elements and their layout in a scene.

94113f59-e716-441e-aa8d-a38f17f21269.llm_explanation: The scene graph in JavaFX is a hierarchical structure of UI nodes that compose the scene, representing the visual elements and their relationships.

5eb1d399-75ac-4036-9f10-c1a9a614c605.llm_explanation: The scene graph in JavaFX is a hierarchical tree structure of UI elements (nodes) that together form the graphical interface of an application.

aa0e5383-1f92-44a8-8ea9-ea813860cdee.llm_explanation: The Scene graph in JavaFX represents the hierarchical structure and layout of all UI components in a window, making option A correct.

58d9e8e6-613f-4954-b18b-abc30c093a85.llm_explanation: The scene graph in JavaFX is a hierarchical tree structure that represents all UI elements in a scene, making option A correct. The other options describe unrelated responsibilities.

6fbb7026-2d57-4f55-b1ad-a18f81a28a3b.llm_explanation: The scene graph in JavaFX is a hierarchical tree structure that manages and organizes all UI components (nodes) in the application window.

4902ff91-410f-4c64-9304-cac950eadf57.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, layout containers like VBox or HBox are used to group multiple UI elements as children, allowing them to be displayed together in the scene graph.

f915ef47-c1ff-4830-8e62-29f79b746a47.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, nodes are added to the scene graph by adding them to a parent container's children list, such as root.getChildren().add(button);. The other options use incorrect methods or classes.

d301291c-d87a-4153-870a-cd2e4f5c5deb.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, only Parent subclasses (like Pane, VBox, etc.) can be used as the root node of a Scene. You must add the Button to a Parent, then set that Parent as the root of the Scene. Option D describes this process correctly.

a5d6b41a-0b32-428e-b261-ef571f584a3a.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, a Parent node is a node that can have child nodes (e.g., Group, Pane), while a Leaf node (like Rectangle, Button) cannot have children. Option D correctly describes this distinction.

488fca55-76fd-42e0-a4d8-3cfc303256c7.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, the root node is the top-level container for all nodes in the scene graph, forming the base of the visual hierarchy. It is required and can be any subclass of Parent, not just Group. Options B, C, and D are incorrect for various reasons.

38e5394e-e93d-42aa-b935-da73e163ee46.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, during event capturing, events travel from the root to the target node (child), and during bubbling, from the target node back up to the root. Thus, event handlers on child nodes are called before parent handlers in both phases.

5cd780fe-dfc0-4bde-9901-c2a5aab90409.llm_explanation: A node must be part of the scene graph to be rendered and to receive events; this is a fundamental requirement in JavaFX. Option B correctly states this, while the other options add unnecessary or incorrect conditions.

bb54c288-d352-4f85-bdb6-9f47d08d2a21.llm_explanation: The scene graph hierarchy in JavaFX directly affects both event propagation (such as mouse/key events) and rendering performance; a poorly structured graph can lead to inefficient rendering and unexpected UI behavior, making proper management essential.

d8fd0daf-f9a8-41b3-b49d-e3807873ef0d.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, some properties (like opacity, transforms, or disabling) are inherited by child nodes, so modifying these on the parent affects the children; other properties are not inherited, so the effect depends on the property.

b43a6a3b-bf90-42d2-8697-16fe90ac91b8.llm_explanation: HBox arranges its child nodes in a single horizontal row, while VBox arranges them vertically, GridPane arranges in a grid, and BorderPane arranges in five regions.

d898730c-27b8-4991-aedf-439f1ea7f21f.llm_explanation: VBox arranges its children in a single vertical column, while the other panes have different layout behaviors.

82785b36-cb6c-4c00-a075-2c9aa567659e.llm_explanation: HBox arranges its child nodes in a single horizontal row, while VBox arranges vertically, StackPane stacks nodes, and BorderPane arranges nodes in five regions.

245c5c2e-67cf-4828-92e4-7d5aae229b39.llm_explanation: VBox arranges its child nodes in a single vertical column, while HBox arranges them horizontally, StackPane stacks them, and GridPane arranges them in a grid.

0262a19d-603f-4897-b81a-14d0ecf799ab.llm_explanation: TilePane arranges its children in a grid of uniformly sized tiles, automatically resizing them to fill available space evenly.

d39343ca-fad5-438b-8abd-728b5ff8d7e7.llm_explanation: HBox arranges its children in a horizontal row, but it does not resize them equally by default; it lays them out in a row with their preferred widths. No standard JavaFX pane resizes all children equally in a row without extra configuration.

b34cc9a3-7993-4dd7-8dc7-c621f97ea1c0.llm_explanation: HBox arranges its children in a single horizontal row with options for consistent spacing, making it the correct choice for this scenario.

940b2d84-db86-4628-b975-69b609cf6bfd.llm_explanation: HBox arranges its child nodes in a single horizontal row and resizes them dynamically with the window.

5977a113-f9b5-4cca-a02f-c8ba255ab3e0.llm_explanation: VBox arranges UI controls vertically in a single column with consistent spacing, which matches the question's requirements.

41c13cad-acf4-4d05-9e7c-2fdedbe8816a.llm_explanation: HBox arranges its children in a single horizontal row and can adjust their sizes to fill available space evenly using HBox.setHgrow.

0287a73a-868f-4e26-8ee1-91df0083377c.llm_explanation: In a BorderPane, the region (top, bottom, center, left, right) to which a child node is assigned determines how it is sized and positioned; the pane manages layout based on these regions, not on direct node properties or CSS.

7c8e3175-51df-49d5-a0ab-fc842f064b66.llm_explanation: GridPane arranges controls in a grid of rows and columns, and controls can span multiple cells using rowSpan and colSpan properties.

a22b53d7-71ef-4d27-9f09-b0fbd693542e.llm_explanation: GridPane allows controls to resize proportionally as its rows and columns can grow and shrink with the window, making it suitable for proportional resizing.

92f3e9c3-3252-4224-b539-1c9b673c7e18.llm_explanation: GridPane arranges nodes in a flexible grid of rows and columns, allowing each cell to resize and fill available space evenly, which is ideal for a resizable grid of UI controls.

60fe4dfb-1c8c-42cd-89ea-fe446c782093.llm_explanation: BorderPane allows flexible, hierarchical arrangement by dividing the layout into five regions (top, bottom, left, right, center), each of which can contain other layout panes, supporting automatic resizing and alignment. GridPane is more suitable for tabular layouts, not general hierarchical arrangements.

fcf29e55-626a-4dee-bc81-60dd1d5ebb4e.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, a Stage represents a window and serves as the main container for displaying Scenes, making option A correct.

3dd862dd-f9bf-4b71-b784-d6c6ca068523.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, the Stage object represents the main window of the application where scenes are set and displayed; it is not responsible for layout, event management, or holding controls directly.

4c5c967c-1ac3-4250-9091-67b706e5f2c1.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, a Stage represents the main window of the application where scenes are set and displayed to the user.

960039c8-d288-4f0d-95da-740a6b653394.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, a Stage represents the main window of the application and serves as a container for scenes, which in turn contain the UI elements.

ca9d87f5-0d64-4998-b3a6-2206f75e714a.llm_explanation: The Stage in JavaFX represents the main window where scenes are set and displayed; it is the top-level container for all JavaFX content.

b228de6e-5922-4122-b92b-3a7e97ef8e99.llm_explanation: The Stage in JavaFX represents the top-level window where the application's content is displayed; it does not manage layout (that's the Scene or layout panes), nor is it a direct container for controls, nor does it directly handle input events.

8f36d6f6-d61f-423f-a429-7819b82cc4d5.llm_explanation: The correct order is to create the Scene with UI nodes, set it on the primaryStage using setScene(), and then call show(). Option B describes this sequence accurately.

9c861825-6071-4499-93e5-1c0793ec9c1f.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, the show() method must be called on a Stage object to display the window after setting its Scene; the other options are not valid Stage methods.

5d423f42-30cc-4ada-932e-bdbc0b543bc6.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, to display a new window, you must create a new Stage, set its Scene, and then call show() on the Stage. Option D correctly describes this process.

7ebda394-de25-4d04-913d-966ef67a9f58.llm_explanation: Each call to setScene(scene) replaces the previous Scene; only the last Scene set before show() is displayed when the Stage is shown.

07da18f0-d791-49b3-8a06-991c3ed257ee.llm_explanation: Calling primaryStage.setScene(scene) assigns the specified Scene to the primary Stage, making its graphical content visible in the main application window; it does not create a new window, initialize event handling, or resize the stage.

54a99c74-c6a2-4dee-8709-4b2a90989edc.llm_explanation: Setting the scene to null after showing the stage removes all content from the window, leaving it empty but still open; no exception is thrown and the window does not close automatically.

5d504836-9434-4ecf-ac48-5b00a8436914.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, each Stage represents a separate window, and each Stage can have its own Scene. To manage multiple windows, you create multiple Stages, each with its own Scene, and show them independently. Option C correctly describes this approach. The other options misuse Scenes or Stages.

1d80d2f6-c160-4a7d-8b63-4e5a92f8cf29.llm_explanation: In JavaFX, calling setScene() multiple times on a Stage before show() will only display the last Scene set; previous Scenes are replaced and not shown.

04d5c6cd-f533-4297-a383-fae4c4f76159.llm_explanation: To display two distinct windows with different scenes in JavaFX, you must create two Stage instances, set a unique Scene on each, and call show() on both. Option B correctly describes this process; the other options are incorrect or incomplete.
